conclusion: To find the magnitude of the induced electromotive force (emf) in the coil, we use Faraday's law of induction, which states that the induced emf is equal to the rate of change of magnetic flux through the coil.

The formula for the emf induced in a rotating coil is given by: \( \varepsilon = n B A \omega \sin(\omega t) \) where: - \( n \) is the number of turns, - \( B \) is the magnetic field strength, - \( A \) is the area of the coil, - \( \omega \) is the angular velocity, - \( t \) is the time.
Since timing starts when the coil plane is in the neutral position, at \( t = 0 \), the sine term is zero, and the emf is zero.
The maximum emf occurs when \( \sin(\omega t) = 1 \).

premise: The side lengths are \( l_{AB}=0.2\mathrm{m} \) and \( l_{BC}=0.5\mathrm{m} \).
conclusion: Calculate the area \( A \) of the coil: \( A = l_{AB} \times l_{BC} = 0.2\, \text{m} \times 0.5\, \text{m} = 0.1\, \text{m}^2 \)

premise: The formula for the maximum emf is \( \varepsilon_{\text{max}} = n B A \omega \).
conclusion: Substitute the known values into the formula for emf: \( \varepsilon_{\text{max}} = 100 \times 0.1\, \text{T} \times 0.1\, \text{m}^2 \times 100\pi\, \text{rad/s} \)
Thus, the magnitude of the induced electromotive force in the coil is approximately \( 314.16\, \text{V} \).
